content.raw:
I like it! Talked to Alejandro, and he said `expressed_in` is correct, whereas `relative_to` is not.

EDIT: To clarify, in the context of the axis vector.
content.html:
I like it! Talked to Alejandro, and he said expressed_in is correct, whereas relative_to is not.

EDIT: To clarify, in the context of the axis vector.

content.raw:
that sounds like a good idea and will help with migration

nit: it could be an attribute of the `xyz` tag: `//joint/axis/xyz[@expressed_in]`
content.html:
that sounds like a good idea and will help with migration

nit: it could be an attribute of the xyz tag: //joint/axis/xyz[@expressed_in]

content.raw: One solution to make \(a\) feasible is to add `//joint/axis[@relative_to]` \(or perhaps more accurately, `@expressed_in`?\), and then transformation is simply replacing `use_parent_model_frame` with `relative_to=”<model>”`, and the joint pose can still be whatevs. Granted, that may make things a bit noisy.
content.html: One solution to make (a) feasible is to add //joint/axis[@relative_to] (or perhaps more accurately, @expressed_in?), and then transformation is simply replacing use_parent_model_frame with relative_to=”<model>”, and the joint pose can still be whatevs. Granted, that may make things a bit noisy.

content.raw:
For compatibility with `//joint/axis/use_parent_model_frame`, is there a way that we can either \(a\) make the 1.6 → 1.7 upgrade accommodate that transformation or \(b\) fail-fast if this attribute is used?

I just spent ~1.5 hours trying to trace down a kinematics bug \([see issue comment](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/issues/12063#issuecomment-532340730)\), and realized it was because this attribute was completely getting dropped, rather than transformed or erroring out.

\(Disturbingly, only one unittest failed in all of Drake due to this bug on the KUKA, which is heavily used…\)

Ideally, \(a\) is somehow feasible?
content.html:
For compatibility with //joint/axis/use_parent_model_frame, is there a way that we can either (a) make the 1.6 → 1.7 upgrade accommodate that transformation or (b) fail-fast if this attribute is used?

I just spent ~1.5 hours trying to trace down a kinematics bug (see issue comment), and realized it was because this attribute was completely getting dropped, rather than transformed or erroring out.

(Disturbingly, only one unittest failed in all of Drake due to this bug on the KUKA, which is heavily used…)

Ideally, (a) is somehow feasible?

content.raw: yeah, I think that makes sense

For [canonical links](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#model-frame-and-canonical-link), I’ve required that `model.LinkCount() > 0` \([in this patch](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/blob/88082b3b48559ec6cabca33c2daf8f9eb4341f8c/multibody/parsing/detail_sdf_parser.cc#L533-L535)\); is this a valid requirement? If so, should this requirement be stated explicitly within the SDFormat proposal we have, and encoded in the validation step?

‌
content.html:
For canonical links, I’ve required that model.LinkCount() > 0 (in this patch); is this a valid requirement? If so, should this requirement be stated explicitly within the SDFormat proposal we have, and encoded in the validation step?

‌

content.raw:
Double ah… It’s because of `detail_scene_graph.h`, `ResolveVisualUri`, which returns a copy of the SDFormat visual thing with the URI replaced… which makes no sense to me…

Will fix that.

EDIT: Done. De-hacked in this commit: [https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/12061/commits/a8083129601a977d997fc4fc399aef5e76e5e491](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/12061/commits/a8083129601a977d997fc4fc399aef5e76e5e491)

‌
content.html:
Double ah… It’s because of detail_scene_graph.h, ResolveVisualUri, which returns a copy of the SDFormat visual thing with the URI replaced… which makes no sense to me…

Will fix that.

EDIT: Done. De-hacked in this commit: https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/12061/commits/a8083129601a977d997fc4fc399aef5e76e5e491

‌

content.raw:
Doing some debugging with this patch, it looks like the graph is passed in, but somehow either the `weak_ptr` is lost, or the `shared_ptr` is somehow invalidated from when the link’s graph is checked to when the viz graph is checked? Injecting print statements in `libsdformat`:

```
[ RUN      ] MultibodyPlantSdfParserTest.PackageMapSpecified
link set graph: box - 0x556f7b830e10
viz set graph: visual - 0x556f7b830e10
  this: 0x556f7b644670
[2019-09-17 01:37:42.606] [console] [info] resolve link pose
link resolve graph: 0x556f7b830e10
[2019-09-17 01:37:42.607] [console] [info] resolve viz pose
viz resolve graph: 0
  this: 0x7ffde0f59cb0
unknown file: Failure
C++ exception with description "From AddModelFromSdfFile():
Error: Visual with name [visual] has invalid pointer to PoseRelativeToGraph.
```

‌
content.html:
Doing some debugging with this patch, it looks like the graph is passed in, but somehow either the weak_ptr is lost, or the shared_ptr is somehow invalidated from when the link’s graph is checked to when the viz graph is checked? Injecting print statements in libsdformat:

[ RUN      ] MultibodyPlantSdfParserTest.PackageMapSpecified
link set graph: box - 0x556f7b830e10
viz set graph: visual - 0x556f7b830e10
  this: 0x556f7b644670
[2019-09-17 01:37:42.606] [console] [info] resolve link pose
link resolve graph: 0x556f7b830e10
[2019-09-17 01:37:42.607] [console] [info] resolve viz pose
viz resolve graph: 0
  this: 0x7ffde0f59cb0
unknown file: Failure
C++ exception with description "From AddModelFromSdfFile():
Error: Visual with name [visual] has invalid pointer to PoseRelativeToGraph.

‌

content.raw: Ah, just looks like the `visual` elements are getting copied or aliased magically. Had briefly hacked `VisualData::poseRelativeToGraph` to be a `shared_ptr`, and it still didn’t work. Printing out `this`, it’s evident that a different visual instance is getting used…
content.html: Ah, just looks like the visual elements are getting copied or aliased magically. Had briefly hacked VisualData::poseRelativeToGraph to be a shared_ptr, and it still didn’t work. Printing out this, it’s evident that a different visual instance is getting used…

update.description:
This is a work in progress branch for implementing Frame Semantics in sdf 1.7 based on the following proposal:

* http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs

This is not yet ready for review. It requires [ign-math pull request 333](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/333/graphalgorithms-add-functions-for-finding/diff).
update.title: WIP: Frame semantics for sdf 1.7

content.raw:
but what should the behavior be for `Joint::ResolvePose(Pose3d&)`? the sdf 1.6 pose would be relative to the child frame, so that would be my inclination

also, it's pretty easy to get the pose of the implicit Joint frame relative to the model frame with `joint->ResolvePose("", pose);`
content.html:
but what should the behavior be for Joint::ResolvePose(Pose3d&)? the sdf 1.6 pose would be relative to the child frame, so that would be my inclination

also, it's pretty easy to get the pose of the implicit Joint frame relative to the model frame with joint->ResolvePose("", pose);

content.raw:
just added `Link::ResolvePose(Pose3d&)` and `Frame::ResolvePose(Pose3d&)` in 59fde13, which give the pose relative to the xml parent

this will be more useful for Collisions and Visuals, so that you don't have to know the name of the parent link
content.html:
just added Link::ResolvePose(Pose3d&) and Frame::ResolvePose(Pose3d&) in 59fde13, which give the pose relative to the xml parent

this will be more useful for Collisions and Visuals, so that you don't have to know the name of the parent link

content.html:
I'm planning to add similar ResolvePose functions to Collision, Visual, etc. but haven't done it yet

in the meantime, there is a static function in FrameSemantics.hh that you have to pass the graph to:

resolvePose(
      const PoseRelativeToGraph &_graph,
      const std::string &_frameName,
      const std::string &_relativeTo,
      ignition::math::Pose3d &_pose)

I can add a quick Model::GetPoseRelativeToGraph() accessor so you can use that in the meantime?

content.raw:
Gotcha; do you when there might be a more generic `GetFramePose(const std::string& relative_to, ignition::math::Pose3d&)`, so I can use it with visuals / collisions?  
EDIT: Updated function prototype.
content.html:
Gotcha; do you when there might be a more generic GetFramePose(const std::string& relative_to, ignition::math::Pose3d&), so I can use it with visuals / collisions?
EDIT: Updated function prototype.

content.raw:
if will work if you build the `ign-math5` branch from source with this one

Link, Joint, and Frame now have `ResolvePose(const std::string &, ignition::math::Pose3d &)` functions that resolve the pose of that object relative to a named frame, using `""` to refer to the implicit model frame.
content.html:
if will work if you build the ign-math5 branch from source with this one

Link, Joint, and Frame now have ResolvePose(const std::string &, ignition::math::Pose3d &) functions that resolve the pose of that object relative to a named frame, using "" to refer to the implicit model frame.

content.raw: Sweet! Is this ready for me to easily try it out in Drake? \(e.g. do I just need to update libsdformat?\)
content.html: Sweet! Is this ready for me to easily try it out in Drake? (e.g. do I just need to update libsdformat?)

content.raw:
some tests are failing because the [ign-math Pose3* operator behavior change](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/301) hasn't been released yet

I'll work on releasing that
content.html:
some tests are failing because the ign-math Pose3* operator behavior change hasn't been released yet

I'll work on releasing that
